title: Every straw counts in the fight against climate change - UNEP
body: Few of us will connect single-use plastic waste to climate change but a report by the Center for International Environmental Law says that the production and disposal of single-use plastics in 2019 caused the equivalent emissions of 189 coal plants, and by 2030 that number could rise to 295.
readable_content:
- Hi Assistant! Can you help me with the 16th December 2019 story from UNEP about the efforts to fight climate change by reducing single-use plastics in Japan?
- Of course! Here is an excerpt from the UNEP story: "Every straw counts in the fight against climate change." The story discusses the impact of single-use plastics on the environment and the efforts of individuals and organizations in Japan to reduce their usage. Specifically, it highlights the efforts of No Plastic Japan, a company that offers alternatives to single-use plastic straws and promotes sustainable living. The article also mentions UNEP's Anatomy of Action campaign, which encourages conscious consumer choices and actions to combat plastic pollution and its impact on climate change.
summary:
The conversation expresses support for the efforts to reduce single-use plastics, particularly plastic straws, in Japan. The focus is on promoting sustainable living and encouraging conscious consumer choices to combat plastic pollution and its impact on climate change. The overall sentiment is positive, highlighting the importance of individual and organizational efforts in addressing this environmental issue.
